pr_body:
<!--
Note: All PRs with code changes should be targeted to the `dev` branch, pure documentation changes can target `main`
-->

## Proposed change

What I like about Paperless is the flexibility to provide a file-based document structure, as this allows for easy consumption of the documents with file-based replication. But, the "one size fits all" solution with `PAPERLESS_FILENAME_FORMAT` is not enough. 

The change is simple: 

- Added storage pathes, where each entry is a different PA
comments: I add the missing documentation part, once you're willing to integrate this.
Thanks for the PR! We will take a look asap. In the meantime this should be targeted to `dev` and rebased on that branch.

> Thanks for the PR! We will take a look asap. In the meantime this should be targeted to `dev` and rebased on that branch.

Sure. Please take a look and give an indication if you're willing to integrate. If yes, I retarget it - should not be a big thing.

This was closed automatically because it was targeting that outdated branch, I will change it to dev

Edit: still needs a re-base

> @shamoon I merged with dev

Thank you, but I think it needs a re-base, theres still a lot of changes that arent yours.

As for the PR itself, I was waiting for others to chime in. Personally, I dont think this is a feature I would use. My preference is to just store docs in some simple way and let paperless handle things from there rather than complicate the file storage. I bet there are some that would, perhaps a vocal group, but IMHO if its not going to get very wide use I dont think I would be in favor of including it as-is since its so prominent, etc (in that case perhaps it could be made optional or something like that?). 

Obviously its not like we have telemetry data or something to have a real clear answer for this, so again, I'd love to hear others' thoughts.
It was a long day ... I rebased it on dev

> As for the PR itself, I was waiting for others to chime in. Personally, I dont think this is a feature I would use. My preference is to just store docs in some simple way and let paperless handle things from there rather than complicate the file storage. I bet there are some that would, perhaps a vocal group, but IMHO if its not going to get very wide use I dont think I would be in favor of including it as-is since its so prominent, etc (in that case perhaps it could be made optional or something like that?).

It's non intrusive. If you don't use storage pathes the system behaves as before. It's like not using correspondents or document types.

I updated the change description with some details and usage info.

Thank you for this PR!

FWIW I would personally find this useful. I work with lots of different shipping labels that make sense to be separate from my health docs, for example. I agree with this:

> But, the "one size fits all" solution with PAPERLESS_FILENAME_FORMAT is not enough.

Regarding the prominence, the tab might feel more intuitive in the settings panel. Although I haven't tested this to confirm.

As shamoon mentioned this is a change that would introduce more long-term maintenance and testing. I think we should leave this up for a while so others can chime in before deciding to continue working and merge. I can help with documentation at that point :)

> As shamoon mentioned this is a change that would introduce more long-term maintenance and testing.

Actually the real change is just "5 lines" in `src/documents/file_handling.py`. It's one place that the whole code base transparently uses to determine a file name.

Everything else is a 100% copy of all other meta classes, behavior, code + adjustment of test-cases.

The change looks huge, but it isn't.

Yea I dont think maintenance is so tough, I do see its largely cloned.

One thing about this at the moment is that the way this is written storage path is treated like document metadata, like something one can search on, filter by, etc. But do you really want that? Is that something people would actually want to do in the way they do for Tags, Correspondents, etc? Perhaps instead they could be tied to metadata, like tied to a correspondent / doc type / tag. Of course thats more complicated and might get messy.

Also the UI would definitely need changes to accommodate another top-level thing like this (that is the filter editor, document cards), Im not sure just adding them on like this will work.

Anyway, yea, lets see.

> One thing about this at the moment is that the way this is written storage path is treated like document metadata, like something one can search on, filter by, etc. But do you really want that? Is that something people would actually want to do in the way they do for Tags, Correspondents, etc? Perhaps instead they could be tied to metadata, like tied to a correspondent / doc type / tag. Of course thats more complicated and might get messy.

I actually implemented this (attached to correspondents, ...) and threw it away afterwards. It doesn't reflect reality: I put a document somewhere, not a correspondent, or a tag. That's again a simplification that tries to mimic behavior that is not related. 
And more important: The auto learning does exactly this. It helps you select a storage path based on correspondent, tags, content, ...

Afterwards I googled some larger document management systems and looked up how they represent hierarchical structures. They make that relation independent of the other metadata - what makes totally sense. This is why I came up with a per document approach.

And yes, I want to be able to search for it, as it most likely requires bulk-change at some point in time. And I can give you many more cases.

I think it's an elegant solution, not too complicated and reuses all patterns of the existing product. 
For me the change is vital, but most likely I'm biased ;)
How do we want to continue here?
I'm not sure yet if I would use the feature, but I'm alright with including it for others.  The backend changes at least aren't too much.

This new feature might solve for quite a few other approaches like e.g. "hierarchical tags".

While I love paperless and being able to find stuff in seconds, reality is that I am not alone. Thus I would like my documents to be filed in at least some meaningful way, so that if get hit by a bus and my docker world dies, my family can still find things.

In the UI world, you design for 50% searchers and 50% browsers. Maybe in paperless the numbers are different, but I do see more than 10 people using this feature. And if the code change and thus maintainance effort is small, I would go for it.

I added a first documentation draft. Comments welcome, I'm not a native speaker.

Also included is a new doc Makefile target `livehtml` that does exactly that: Preview with live reload. I added `sphinx-autobuild` to the dev dependencies for that.
I'm very happy to see the project being active again. A lot changes to be merged down every day but that's definitely a 👍
Not sure if I can change it, but we should probably add a requirement of at least one other reviewer.

> Not sure if I can change it, but we should probably add a requirement of at least one other reviewer.

An admin should be able to adjust the branch protection settings: https://github.blog/2018-03-23-require-multiple-reviewers/
Yes this is not ready to merge from a frontend standpoint. I have a bunch of thoughts but I dont want to ask for changes in case this doesnt end up getting merged. Unless youre ok with that @mskg

This is already a lot of work and needs daily adjustments. Postponing the merge now would be a waste of the last efforts.

From UI perspective it doesn't violate any existing patterns and is usable in the same way as the rest of the application. If you see something totally blocking, just let me know and I try to fix it.

I think it's definitely stable enough to merge it down to dev. We don't need to overengineer. Improving it later is totally fine for me - also helping with that.

> This is already a lot of work and needs daily adjustments. Postponing the merge now would be a waste of the last efforts.
> 
> Improving it later is totally fine for me - also helping with that. But it's definitely stable enough to merge it down to dev.

Sorry no I do not agree. This is not complete from an implementation standpoint and I am not ok with merging as is. I dont just mean that the code will merge via git, I mean I am no OK with the frontend implementation.  I will leave a review now.

I think this is something a decent number of people would find useful.  And at least on the backend, it isn't actually too much changes.  And the backwards compatibility means  people can opt in if they have uses for it or ignore it otherwise
Like I said, no problem to remove showstoppers. Waiting for your feedback.
Ps. Definitely appreciate your work on this, I dont mean to gloss over that at all.

> Ps. Definitely appreciate your work on this, I dont mean to gloss over that at all.

No worries. Let’s just focus on the most important points and do the other things as an optimization. We ship and get feedback - there will be more to do.

Another broader question I have is: if no new paths are created, presumably they all use the setting from `PAPERLESS_FILENAME_FORMAT` (or the default) but currently the UI doesnt really make that apparent anywhere, which is sort of confusing. Like perhaps we should indicate that to the user. And btw, the UI would need a way to remove the current path and "reset" it to default.

> Another broader question I have is: if no new paths are created, presumably they all use the setting from `PAPERLESS_FILENAME_FORMAT` (or the default) but currently the UI doesnt really make that apparent anywhere, which is sort of confusing. Like perhaps we should indicate that to the user. 

„Default“ ?

> And btw, the UI would need a way to remove the current path and "reset" it to default.

It‘s there - same as for all inputs - the little ‚X‘.

> Let’s just focus on the most important points and do the other things as an optimization. We ship and get feedback - there will be more to do.

Well I do agree that we'll get feedback but I believe these are not small concerns. As this feature actually alters the files on disk and theres no "undo" I do think we need to refine it as much as we can. Yes, its not going to cause data loss but in general the UI doesnt make many changes to files like this (other than actually deleting files).

Dont worry, Im sure there will be feedback after its released! =)

diff --git a/docs/Makefile b/docs/Makefile
index cf5dbff6aed..7890f98289a 100644
--- a/docs/Makefile
+++ b/docs/Makefile
@@ -24,6 +24,7 @@ I18NSPHINXOPTS  = $(PAPEROPT_$(PAPER)) $(SPHINXOPTS) .
 help:
 	@echo "Please use \`make <target>' where <target> is one of"
 	@echo "  html       to make standalone HTML files"
+	@echo "  livehtml   to preview changes with live reload in your browser"
 	@echo "  dirhtml    to make HTML files named index.html in directories"
 	@echo "  singlehtml to make a single large HTML file"
 	@echo "  pickle     to make pickle files"
@@ -54,6 +55,9 @@ html:
 	@echo
 	@echo "Build finished. The HTML pages are in $(BUILDDIR)/html."
 
+livehtml:
+	sphinx-autobuild "./" "$(BUILDDIR)" $(O)
+
 dirhtml:
 	$(SPHINXBUILD) -b dirhtml $(ALLSPHINXOPTS) $(BUILDDIR)/dirhtml
 	@echo
diff --git a/docs/_static/js/darkmode.js b/docs/_static/js/darkmode.js
index 49cf0eeec0f..90947258713 100644
--- a/docs/_static/js/darkmode.js
+++ b/docs/_static/js/darkmode.js
@@ -1,47 +1,47 @@
-let toggleButton;
-let icon;
+let toggleButton
+let icon
 
 function load() {
-	"use strict";
+	'use strict'
 
-	toggleButton = document.createElement("button");
-	toggleButton.setAttribute("title", "Toggle dark mode");
-	toggleButton.classList.add("dark-mode-toggle");
-	icon = document.createElement("i");
-	icon.classList.add("fa", darkModeState ? "fa-sun-o" : "fa-moon-o");
-	toggleButton.appendChild(icon);
-	document.body.prepend(toggleButton);
+	toggleButton = document.createElement('button')
+	toggleButton.setAttribute('title', 'Toggle dark mode')
+	toggleButton.classList.add('dark-mode-toggle')
+	icon = document.createElement('i')
+	icon.classList.add('fa', darkModeState ? 'fa-sun-o' : 'fa-moon-o')
+	toggleButton.appendChild(icon)
+	document.body.prepend(toggleButton)
 
 	// Listen for changes in the OS settings
 	// addListener is used because older versions of Safari don't support addEventListener
 	// prefersDarkQuery set in <head>
 	if (prefersDarkQuery) {
 		prefersDarkQuery.addListener(function (evt) {
-			toggleDarkMode(evt.matches);
-		});
+			toggleDarkMode(evt.matches)
+		})
 	}
 
 	// Initial setting depending on the prefers-color-mode or localstorage
 	// darkModeState should be set in the document <head> to prevent flash
-	if (darkModeState == undefined) darkModeState = false;
-	toggleDarkMode(darkModeState);
+	if (darkModeState == undefined) darkModeState = false
+	toggleDarkMode(darkModeState)
 
 	// Toggles the "dark-mode" class on click and sets localStorage state
-	toggleButton.addEventListener("click", () => {
-		darkModeState = !darkModeState;
+	toggleButton.addEventListener('click', () => {
+		darkModeState = !darkModeState
 
-		toggleDarkMode(darkModeState);
-		localStorage.setItem("dark-mode", darkModeState);
-	});
+		toggleDarkMode(darkModeState)
+		localStorage.setItem('dark-mode', darkModeState)
+	})
 }
 
 function toggleDarkMode(state) {
-	document.documentElement.classList.toggle("dark-mode", state);

 Hooking into the consumption process
 ####################################
@@ -268,6 +269,17 @@ If paperless detects that two documents share the same filename, paperless will
 append ``_01``, ``_02``, etc to the filename. This happens if all the placeholders in a filename
 evaluate to the same value.
 
+.. hint::
+    You can affect how empty placeholders are treated by changing the following setting to
+    `true`.
+
+    .. code::
+
+        PAPERLESS_FILENAME_FORMAT_REMOVE_NONE=True
+
+    Doing this results in all empty placeholders resolving to "" instead of "none" as stated above.
+    Spaces before empty placeholders are removed as well, empty directories are omitted.
+
 .. hint::
 
     Paperless checks the filename of a document whenever it is saved. Therefore,
@@ -290,3 +302,59 @@ evaluate to the same value.
 
     However, keep in mind that inside docker, if files get stored outside of the
     predefined volumes, they will be lost after a restart of paperless.
+
+
+Storage paths
+#############
+
+One of the best things in Paperless is that you can not only access the documents via the
+web interface, but also via the file system.
+
+When as single storage layout is not sufficient for your use case, storage paths come to
+the rescue. Storage paths allow you to configure more precisely where each document is stored
+in the file system.
+
+- Each storage path is a `PAPERLESS_FILENAME_FORMAT` and follows the rules described above
+- Each document is assigned a storage path using the matching algorithms described above, but
+  can be overwritten at any time
+
+For example, you could define the following two storage paths:
+
+1. Normal communications are put into a folder structure sorted by `year/correspondent`
+2. Communications with insurance companies are stored in a flat structure with longer file names,
+   but containing the full date of the correspondence.
+
+.. code::
+
+    By Year = {created_year}/{correspondent}/{title}
+    Insurances = Insurances/{correspondent}/{created_year}-{created_month}-{created_day} {title}
+
+
+If you then map these storage paths to the documents, you might get the following result.
+For simplicity, `By Year` defines the same structure as in the previous example above.
+
+.. code:: text
+
+   2019/                                   # By Year
+      My bank/
+        Statement January.pdf
+        Statement February.pdf
+
+    Insurances/                           # Insurances
+      Healthcare 123/
+        2022-01-01 Statement January.pdf
+        2022-02-02 Letter.pdf
+        2022-02-03 Letter.pdf
+      Dental 456/
+        2021-12-01 New Conditions.pdf
+
+
+.. hint::
+
+    Defining a storage path is optional. If no storage path is defined for a document, the global
+    `PAPERLESS_FILENAME_FORMAT` is applied.
+
+.. caution::
+
+    If you adjust the format of an existing storage path, old documents don't get relocated automatically.
+    You need to run the :ref:`document renamer <utilities-renamer>` to adjust their pathes.

+PAPERLESS_FILENAME_FORMAT_REMOVE_NONE=<bool>
+    Tells paperless to replace placeholders in `PAPERLESS_FILENAME_FORMAT` that would resolve
+    to 'none' to be omitted from the resulting filename. This also holds true for directory
+    names.
+    See :ref:`advanced-file_name_handling` for details.

+++ b/src-ui/src/app/components/common/edit-dialog/storage-path-edit-dialog/storage-path-edit-dialog.component.ts
@@ -0,0 +1,50 @@
+import { Component } from '@angular/core'
+import { FormControl, FormGroup } from '@angular/forms'
+import { NgbActiveModal } from '@ng-bootstrap/ng-bootstrap'
+import { EditDialogComponent } from 'src/app/components/common/edit-dialog/edit-dialog.component'
+import { PaperlessStoragePath } from 'src/app/data/paperless-storage-path'
+import { StoragePathService } from 'src/app/services/rest/storage-path.service'
+import { ToastService } from 'src/app/services/toast.service'
+
+@Component({
+  selector: 'app-storage-path-edit-dialog',
+  templateUrl: './storage-path-edit-dialog.component.html',
+  styleUrls: ['./storage-path-edit-dialog.component.scss'],
+})
+export class StoragePathEditDialogComponent extends EditDialogComponent<PaperlessStoragePath> {
+  constructor(
+    service: StoragePathService,
+    activeModal: NgbActiveModal,
+    toastService: ToastService
+  ) {
+    super(service, activeModal, toastService)
+  }
+
+  get pathHint() {
+    return (
+      $localize`e.g.` +
+      ' <code>{created_year}-{title}</code> ' +
+      $localize`or use slashes to add directories e.g.` +
+      ' <code>{created_year}/{correspondent}/{title}</code>. ' +
+      $localize`See <a target="_blank" href="https://paperless-ngx.readthedocs.io/en/latest/advanced_usage.html#file-name-handling">documentation</a> for full list.`
+    )
+  }
+
+  getCreateTitle() {
+    return $localize`Create new storage path`
+  }
+
+  getEditTitle() {
+    return $localize`Edit storage path`
+  }
+
+  getForm(): FormGroup {
+    return new FormGroup({
+      name: new FormControl(''),
+      path: new FormControl(''),
+      matching_algorithm: new FormControl(1),
+      match: new FormControl(''),
+      is_insensitive: new FormControl(true),
+    })
+  }
+}

--- /dev/null

@@ -0,0 +1,48 @@
+import { Component } from '@angular/core'
+import { NgbModal } from '@ng-bootstrap/ng-bootstrap'
+import { FILTER_STORAGE_PATH } from 'src/app/data/filter-rule-type'
+import { PaperlessStoragePath } from 'src/app/data/paperless-storage-path'
+import { DocumentListViewService } from 'src/app/services/document-list-view.service'
+import { QueryParamsService } from 'src/app/services/query-params.service'
+import { StoragePathService } from 'src/app/services/rest/storage-path.service'
+import { ToastService } from 'src/app/services/toast.service'
+import { StoragePathEditDialogComponent } from '../../common/edit-dialog/storage-path-edit-dialog/storage-path-edit-dialog.component'
+import { ManagementListComponent } from '../management-list/management-list.component'
+
+@Component({
+  selector: 'app-storage-path-list',
+  templateUrl: './../management-list/management-list.component.html',
+  styleUrls: ['./../management-list/management-list.component.scss'],
+})
+export class StoragePathListComponent extends ManagementListComponent<PaperlessStoragePath> {
+  constructor(
+    directoryService: StoragePathService,
+    modalService: NgbModal,
+    toastService: ToastService,
+    queryParamsService: QueryParamsService
+  ) {
+    super(
+      directoryService,
+      modalService,
+      StoragePathEditDialogComponent,
+      toastService,
+      queryParamsService,
+      FILTER_STORAGE_PATH,
+      $localize`storage path`,
+      $localize`storage paths`,
+      [
+        {
+          key: 'path',
+          name: $localize`Path`,
+          valueFn: (c: PaperlessStoragePath) => {
+            return c.path
+          },
+        },
+      ]
+    )
+  }
+
+  getDeleteMessage(object: PaperlessStoragePath) {
+    return $localize`Do you really want to delete the storage path "${object.name}"?`
+  }
+}

+def set_storage_path(
+    sender,
+    document=None,
+    logging_group=None,
+    classifier=None,
+    replace=False,
+    use_first=True,
+    suggest=False,
+    base_url=None,
+    color=False,
+    **kwargs,
+):
+    if document.storage_path and not replace:
+        return
+
+    potential_storage_path = matching.match_storage_paths(
+        document,
+        classifier,
+    )
+
+    potential_count = len(potential_storage_path)
+    if potential_storage_path:
+        selected = potential_storage_path[0]
+    else:
+        selected = None
+
+    if potential_count > 1:
+        if use_first:
+            logger.info(
+                f"Detected {potential_count} potential storage paths, "
+                f"so we've opted for {selected}",
+                extra={"group": logging_group},
+            )
+        else:
+            logger.info(
+                f"Detected {potential_count} potential storage paths, "
+                f"not assigning any storage directory",
+                extra={"group": logging_group},
+            )
+            return
+
+    if selected or replace:
+        if suggest:
+            if base_url:
+                print(
+                    termcolors.colorize(str(document), fg="green")
+                    if color
+                    else str(document),
+                )
+                print(f"{base_url}/documents/{document.pk}")
+            else:
+                print(
+                    (
+                        termcolors.colorize(str(document), fg="green")
+                        if color
+                        else str(document)
+                    )
+                    + f" [{document.pk}]",
+                )
+            print(f"Sugest storage directory {selected}")
+        else:
+            logger.info(
+                f"Assigning storage path {selected} to {document}",
+                extra={"group": logging_group},
+            )
+
+            document.storage_path = selected
+            document.save(update_fields=("storage_path",))
+
+
 @receiver(models.signals.post_delete, sender=Document)

     with FileLock(settings.MEDIA_LOCK):

This PR is
comments: If you prefer to fix the failing exporter tests in a different way I'm open to suggestions

One thing I see missing is documentation.  What are the new settings?  And how does `SOCIALACCOUNT_PROVIDERS` get configured by a user?

I don't know much about this area, so I need that to try and test with Authelia.

@mpflanzer Did you intentionally disable pushing to your branch or not intentional? Theres a checkbox somewhere I think. If you would prefer we not do that its fine, but I have a few commits that fix the frontend coverage and other small frontend-only things

Another big question is what happens when a new user gets created. I havent tested that, but I presume they will have 0 permissions to start, which is an issue. Making progress on the UI, again let us know if youre OK with pushing to your branch.

> @mpflanzer Did you intentionally disable pushing to your branch or not intentional? Theres a checkbox somewhere I think. If you would prefer we not do that its fine, but I have a few commits that fix the frontend coverage and other small frontend-only things

No not intentionally at all. Changes are welcome. It seems that option doesn't exist because I created the PR based on a fork owned by an organization and not my personal account. :see_no_evil: Do you want me to close this one and open a new one from my personal account?


> One thing I see missing is documentation. What are the new settings? And how does `SOCIALACCOUNT_PROVIDERS` get configured by a user?
> 
> I don't know much about this area, so I need that to try and test with Authelia.

Here is a pretty comprehensive list of how to setup providers: https://docs.allauth.org/en/latest/socialaccount/providers/index.html Authelia is not on that list but I presume it's similar to Keycloak (which I used for testing).

> It seems that option doesn't exist because I created the PR based on a fork owned by an organization and not my personal account.

Oh, interesting. What if you give us access to the repository (not the org)? I think that would do it?
Done. Let me know if I should add more people.

> Another big question is what happens when a new user gets created. I havent tested that, but I presume they will have 0 permissions to start, which is an issue.

Correct, but we can override the `populate_user` method (https://github.com/pennersr/django-allauth/blob/4c3b84a058b4bf3f9ea8fac72e053e90039bbebc/allauth/socialaccount/adapter.py#L105) in the social account adapter to customize what is supposed to happen.

today i tested the current commit 7ab60027 from the branch mpflanzer-allauth from https://github.com/chickadee-engineering:mpflanzer-allauth.

I got a working login with a OpenID Connect auth done with goAuthentik. The setup may be reproducable with other OIDC solutions like Authelia as well. 

Steps to reproduce:

- Create Authentication Provider of type "OAuth2/OpenID Provider" in goAuthentik
- Copy information from from Provider created provider to notepad:
  - OpenID Configuration Issuer (URL)
  - Client ID
  - Client Secret
- Create Application in goAuthentik
  - UI Settings > Launch URL: "http://localhost:8010" (if you are testing on localhost or the url of your paperless instance)
- switch to paperless-ngx
- goto settings > open Django-Adminpanel > Accounts > Social Apps > add
  - provider: OpenID Connect
  - provider id: choose something which is uniq and describes the current social app, e.g. "auth-mycompany" (is inserted to the login url and referenced in the user accounts)
  - name: e.g. "mycompany" or "auth.mycompany.tld" (is shown as label at the login button)
  - client-id: paste "Client ID" value from notepad
  - secret key: paste "Client Secret" value from notepad
  - settings: {"server_url": "https://..."} - paste your OpenID Configuration Issuer URL from notepad

Re https://github.com/paperless-ngx/paperless-ngx/pull/5190#discussion_r1439066755:

I'll have to look into this further (I haven't had a chance to deploy paperless yet), but being able to map permissions from a scope/claim would be great - I'll hopefully be able to take a look at this pretty soon so I can report back with more details. I can provide more info/test with my IDP (Kanidm) if needed as well.

Also a side note about permissions - if scopes/claims are supported for setting these, it would make sense in my mind to provide the user with no access unless otherwise specified (by scopes/claims) - it follows the principle of least privilege, and means that users must make a conscious decision to grant permissions.

The code snippet you posted was a bit different. The key of the provider needs to be `github` (not `openid_connect`). Basically you need to merge the to sections you had.
I didn't use Django admin for my test. Everything was working by just using the settings file.

Ah sweet, thats great. Yea was hoping it would be just set it once kinda thing for users. As I said, when we get there documentation will be good 😆. Presumably a lot of it I'll be linking to all-auth, etc.

Ps. In general, I dont think this PR is very far, but the other thing is we've just released a bunch of new big-ish features so we're just a bit focused on shoring those up for now. But Im hopeful this can eventually get 'over the line', thanks for your patience

I have setup oidc via Django admin and I wonder if modifying settings.py needs to be mention for docker via env variables and how. Because theoretical there can be as many social logins as the admin wants.

I'm very interested in OIDC too.
Can I help in any way?

I have tandoor with django-allauth connected to my authentik instance and I could share the configuration if that would help.

In case the allauth solution isn't welcome, I could also help with implementing a more basic OIDC integration.
I already contributed a (janky) OIDC connector for another open source project. It's not perfect, but if you only support a subset of possible configurations, you can allready connect most OIDC implementations.

Either way, I'd be happy to support this feature :)

> I'll have to look into this further (I haven't had a chance to deploy paperless yet), but being able to map permissions from a scope/claim would be great

Isn't this kind of the wrong way round? Paperless would ask for a certain scope and the user can decide to grant permission or decline. But for the permissions it shouldn't be the user deciding but some kind of admin. Or is there also a way to configure the OAuth App, for instance in Github, to only allow certain scopes?

> Isn't this kind of the wrong way round? Paperless would ask for a certain scope and the user can decide to grant permission or decline. But for the permissions it shouldn't be the user deciding but some kind of admin. Or is there also a way to configure the OAuth App, for instance in Github, to only allow certain scopes?

As I understand it the proper way to do this is actually to associate the user with specific groups in the SSO application and have those groups mapped to groups in Paperless-ngx, then those groups will have the granted permissions associated as configured by the admin.

But this requires that I have control over the identity provider. If I connect to GitHub for instance I guess there is no way of creating groups etc. So in the first case that would be nice to leverage but it wouldn't solve the permission question in general.

But would it be an issue to start with no permissions and wait for an admin to assign permissions? Currently "signup" is also manually done by an admin, right?

There are several ways to handle this from an identity provider perspective. In for example AzureAD (or "EntraID" as it is now called) you can work both with groups to assign certain permissions to certain people, and also often you can assign a profile to a person, which is basically an additional information which gets sent to the attached application and then handled in a certain way.

As others have said, this is dependent on both the respective identity provider and how the application has implemented its rights management and there is not always a uniform way.

As a first step, just the possibility to assign a certain default profile to people logging in via the identity provider for the first time would be a good starting point in my opinion.

> Isn't this kind of the wrong way round? Paperless would ask for a certain scope and the user can decide to grant permission or decline. But for the permissions it shouldn't be the user deciding but some kind of admin. Or is there also a way to configure the OAuth App, for instance in Github, to only allow certain scopes?

Yes, it is typically up to the identity provider. For things like github, where you don't have control, it doesn't make sense - but for something self hosted such as Authelia, Kanidm, or Authentik, you have the ability to map custom claims/scopes. 

In OIDC, a claim is a piece of information about the user. By default, there are standard claims like email address, subject (a UUID for the user), first/last name, preferred name (username/displayname) etc. This can also include information such as membership of a group, which is typically used to indicate permissions.
A scope, on the other hand, is a collection of claims - the default scope `profile` includes many of the things above like email, username etc.

An Oauth2 resource server (Paperless) can request arbitrary scopes and/or claims from the identity provider, which it can use in any way it sees fit. It could take the presence of the scope `paperless-admin` to indicate that a user has administrative access to the paperless server (even if the scope has no claims, more info in a sec). Though I haven't had a chance to deploy paperless yet, I believe I saw that it already has the concept of role-based access control (permissions through groups) - the simplest way to implement this would be to allow the user to map a scope/claim from the IdP to a group in paperless, but it would be better UX wise to have a couple of pre-set scopes/claims (i.e. `paperless-admin`) that automatically map to the relevant group/role in paperless.

One other thing to keep in mind is usernames - some smaller projects incorrectly use `preferred_username` or `username` to associate a user from the IdP to a user in the resource server. This is bad because the uniqueness of these claims is not guaranteed - a user can change these at any time, according to the RFC. Some IdPs do guarantee the uniqueness of these claims, but again, it is not guaranteed according to the RFC. Instead, the claim `sub` should be used. This is typically a non-human readable UUID, but is guaranteed to be immutable per account creation. It is up to the resource server to implement a display name/pretty name, so that the user sees `TheRealGramdalf` in the UI  as opposed to `some-random-uuid`. The claim `preferred_username` is typically used for the display name.

One other thing to note is that with OIDC, the user typically doesn't enter their username/password in the resource servers login UI - instead, they click on a link that takes them to their IdP (such as google, github, etc), where they login with the typical flow. Unless paperless decides to do things differently, there shouldn't be a need to have any correlation between username and UUID in the login page - this would be a purely visual substitution.

Let me know if that makes sense, I can provide further info if need be.

Also forgot to mention - mapping a scope/claim to permissions in paperless should be off by default (since the user does not necessarily have complete control over a user's scopes for e.g. github), and the user can enable it if needed. By default, users authenticating via OIDC should have no access - they should be able to log in, but not have access to any data, read or write. It is assumed that the IdP is trusted - if the user has a scope/claim (due to the resource server-specific nature of OIDC/Oauth2), it is assumed that the IdP is making sure that a user only has the scopes they should.

Grafana has a very good (and RFC compliant) implementation of OIDC/Oauth2 - here's a [link to the overview](https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-security/configure-authentication/generic-oauth/), an [integration planning brief](https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-security/planning-iam-strategy/), and the [authentication configuration reference](https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-grafana/#auth) (and the [oauth2 specific section](https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/setup-grafana/configure-grafana/#authgeneric_oauth) of said configuration reference)

Thanks for the details @TheRealGramdalf. That's matching how I pictured it. `django-allauth` is using the `sub` claim to link a social account to a local user account. And the login happens, as you said, by redirecting to the IdP.

So to summarize a bit the discussion:
- By default users are able to signup via social auth but have no permissions until an admin assigns them some
- Existing local users can link their social account and keep all the permissions they had already
- For convenience it would be nice to derive permissions/groups from claims/scopes returned by the IdP.

The first two points is the current state of the branch. I would propose to keep the third point as a next step out of scope of this PR.

> The first two points is the current state of the branch. I would propose to keep the third point as a next step out of scope of this PR.

I concur. Is there a docker image I can use to test drive this with my chosen SSO solution, Kanidm? Or would I have to build it from the branch over at https://github.com/chickadee-engineering:mpflanzer-allauth?

You need to build by yourself.

`docker compose -f path/to/choosen-docker-compose.yml build`

to build it. And then start it

`docker compose -f path/to/choosen-docker-compose.yml up -d`

I was also able to get my provider (Kanidm) functional with the following configuration:
*Replace text in `<brackets>` with the correct value for your case, e.g. `kanidm group create <login-group-name>` becomes `kanidm group create paperless-ngx-openid`*

### Docker image
- Clone the repository: `git clone -b mpflanzer-allauth https://github.com/chickadee-engineering/paperless-ngx`
    - *Using commit `git log`: `commit 9a71c979da873e9b4fe7f98205212049c3f66a0d`*
- Build the docker image: `cd paperless-ngx && docker build --tag paperless-ngx:mpflanzer-allauth --network=host .`

### Kanidm
- Add an Oauth2 resource server  (`kanidm system oauth2 create <client-id> '<Display Name>' 'https://paperless.my.domain.tld'`)
    - Create a group for users that are allowed to log in (`kanidm group create <login-group-name>`)
    - Add scope map for `openid`, `profile`, and `email` (all of which are requested by Paperless-ngx) (`kanidm system oauth2 create-scope-map <client-id> <login-group-name> openid profile email`)
    - Add a user to the group (`kanidm group add-members <login-group-name> <allowed-user-1> <allowed-user-2>`)
- Get the basic secret (`kanidm system oauth2 show-basic-secret <client-id>`)

### Paperless
- Since paperless is behind a proxy, set `PAPERLESS_PROXY_SSL_HEADER='["HTTP_X_FORWARDED_PROTO", "https"]'`
    - *This makes sure paperless is aware that it's running via https, see the [paperless docs](https://docs.paperless-ngx.com/configuration/#PAPERLESS_PROXY_SSL_HEADER) and the [django docs](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/4.2/ref/settings/#secure-proxy-ssl-header)*
- Enable the generic OpenID provider by setting `PAPERLESS_APPS='allauth.socialaccount.providers.openid_connect'`
    - *For more well known providers, you could use their preset instead*
- Configure the provider via an environment variable: `PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_PROVIDERS='{ "openid_connect": { "APPS": [ { "provider_id": "kanidm", "name": "Paperless Display Name", "client_id": "<client-id>", "secret": "alskdjflkassdjf-client-secret-herelakjdsflkjassdf", "settings": { "server_url": "https://auth.domain.tld/oauth2/openid/<client-id>" } } ], "OAUTH_PKCE_ENABLED": "True" } }'`

Readable version:
```jsonc
{
    "openid_connect": {
        "APPS": [
            {
                "provider_id": "kanidm", // Choose whatever ID you want (inserted to the login url and referenced in the user accounts)
                "name": "Paperless Display Name", // Choose a human-readable user facing name (shown as label at the login button)
                "client_id": "<client-id>", // Use the client id from Kanidm
                "secret": "alskdjflkassdjf-client-secret-herelakjdsflkjassdf", // Insert your actual secret here
                "settings": {
                    "server_url": "https://auth.domain.tld/oauth2/openid/<client-id>" // Replace <client-id> with the client id from Kanidm 
                }
            }
        ],
        "OAUTH_PKCE_ENABLED": "True" // Required specifically for Kanidm, since PKCE is enforced by default (not using PKCE is considered insecure). See https://docs.allauth.org/en/latest/socialaccount/providers/okta.html#okta for an example
    }
}
```
>

I have made some progress testing with Authelia as a OIDC provider, but this still needs:

- Documentation.  At a very least, the new settings and ideally some example configurations for the more common providers someone self hosting will use (Authentik and Authelia come to mind).  These could be maintained in the wiki or upstreamed if the provider has that sort of thing in documentation
- A user should be able to set `ACCOUNT_DEFAULT_HTTP_PROTOCOL`, and this should default to `https`, not allauth's default of http.  Secure by default seems best
- I'm fine with initial permissions needing to be added manually by an admin, in this initial support

As far as initial permissions go, there were a couple things I had in mind:
- It looks like when a user first signs in, they can still upload documents (and therefore use space etc) - that could be a concern especially with things like github, where you can't necessarily control who can access it (as far as I know, I haven't tried yet though)
- Not sure how this would be implemented, but it would be nice if I didn't have to enable OpenID connect with `PAPERLESS_APPS='allauth.socialaccount.providers.openid_connect'`, since I already specified a provider with `PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_PROVIDERS`. 
- When I was doing setup I ran across a note saying that documents without an owner are by default visible to everyone - that might also be worth noting, but I'm not quite sure how that would work with the consume folder - if someone uploads documents (i.e. via a generic SMB share), who should be assigned as the owner? Unless user-authenticated uploads are enforced, I don't see an easy way to make this secure by default (apart from disabling the consume folder entirely).
    - The easiest way I can think to solve this long term would be to have a tighter consume integration (keeping in mind that I haven't really _used_ paperless-ngx yet - this could well be implemented already) such that users could connect via WebDAV, SFTP (aka SSHFS) or something else that's bound to their account so documents can be properly assigned. Of course, an admin could create this "integration" with custom tagging rules (via folder) and separate shares, but having it integrated directly would be very nice. 

But I digress - the last point is definitely out of scope of this initial PR - if there isn't an easier solution, I would probably just disable the consume folder by default (making it opt-in for users who enable OIDC) and show the user a warning with the security implications.

+
+## SSO and third party authentication with Paperless-ngx
+
+Paperless-ngx has a built-in authentication system from Django but you can easily integrate an
+external authentication solution using one of the following methods:
+
+### Remote User authentication
+
+This is a simple option that uses remote user authentication made available by certain SSO
+applications. See the relevant configuration options for more information:
+[PAPERLESS_ENABLE_HTTP_REMOTE_USER](configuration.md#PAPERLESS_ENABLE_HTTP_REMOTE_USER) and
+[PAPERLESS_HTTP_REMOTE_USER_HEADER_NAME](configuration.md#PAPERLESS_HTTP_REMOTE_USER_HEADER_NAME)
+
+### OpenID Connect and social authentication
+
+Version 2.5.0 of Paperless-ngx added support for integrating other authentication systems via
+the [django-allauth](https://github.com/pennersr/django-allauth) package. Once set up, users
+can either log in or (optionally) sign up using any third party systems you integrate. See the
+relevant [configuration settings](configuration.md#PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_PROVIDERS) and
+[django-allauth docs](https://docs.allauth.org/en/latest/socialaccount/configuration.html)
+for more information.
+
+As an example, to set up login via Github, the following environment variables would need to be
+set:
+
+```conf
+PAPERLESS_APPS="allauth.socialaccount.providers.github"
+PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_PROVIDERS='{"github": {"APPS": [{"provider_id": "github","name": "Github","client_id": "<CLIENT_ID>","secret": "<CLIENT_SECRET>"}]}}'
+```
+
+Or, to use OpenID Connect ("OIDC"), via Keycloak in this example:
+
+```conf
+PAPERLESS_APPS="allauth.socialaccount.providers.openid_connect"
+PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_PROVIDERS='
+{"openid_connect": {"APPS": [{"provider_id": "keycloak","name": "Keycloak","client_id": "paperless","secret": "<CLIENT_SECRET>","settings": { "server_url": "https://<KEYCLOAK_SERVER>/realms/<REALM>/.well-known/openid-configuration"}}]}}'
+```
+
+More details about configuration option for various providers can be found in the allauth documentation: https://docs.allauth.org/en/latest/socialaccount/providers/index.html#provider-specifics

+#### [`PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_PROVIDERS=<json>`](#PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_PROVIDERS) {#PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_PROVIDERS}
+
+: This variable is used to setup login and signup via social account providers which are compatible with django-allauth.
+See the corresponding [django-allauth documentation](https://docs.allauth.org/en/0.60.0/socialaccount/providers/index.html)
+for a list of provider configurations. You will also likely need to include the relevant Django 'application' inside the
+[PAPERLESS_APPS](#PAPERLESS_APPS) setting.
+
+    Defaults to None, which does not enable any third party authentication systems.
+
+#### [`PAPERLESS_SOCIAL_AUTO_SIGNUP=<bool>`](#PAPERLESS_SOCIAL_AUTO_SIGNUP) {#PAPERLESS_SOCIAL_AUTO_SIGNUP}
+
+: Attempt to signup the user using retrieved email, username etc from the third party authentication
+system. See the corresponding
+[django-allauth documentation](https://docs.allauth.org/en/0.60.0/socialaccount/configuration.html)
+
+    Defaults to False
+
+#### [`PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS=<bool>`](#PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS) {#PAPERLESS_SOCIALACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS}
+
+: Allow users to signup for a new Paperless-ngx account using any setup third party authentication systems.
+
+    Defaults to True
+
+#### [`PAPERLESS_ACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS=<bool>`](#PAPERLESS_ACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS) {#PAPERLESS_ACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS}
+
+: Allow users to signup for a new Paperless-ngx account.
+
+    Defaults to False
+
+#### [`PAPERLESS_ACCOUNT_DEFAULT_HTTP_PROTOCOL=<string>`](#PAPERLESS_ACCOUNT_DEFAULT_HTTP_PROTOCOL) {#PAPERLESS_ACCOUNT_DEFAULT_HTTP_PROTOCOL}
+
+: The protocol used when generating URLs, e.g. login callback URLs. See the corresponding
+[django-allauth documentation](https://docs.allauth.org/en/latest/account/configuration.html)
+
+    Defaults to 'https'
+

diff --git a/src-ui/src/app/services/django-messages.service.spec.ts b/src-ui/src/app/services/django-messages.service.spec.ts
new file mode 100644
index 00000000000..5e95f32f4b5
--- /dev/null
+++ b/src-ui/src/app/services/django-messages.service.spec.ts
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@
+import { TestBed } from '@angular/core/testing'
+
+import {
+  DjangoMessageLevel,
+  DjangoMessagesService,
+} from './django-messages.service'
+
+const messages = [
+  { level: DjangoMessageLevel.ERROR, message: 'Error Message' },
+  { level: DjangoMessageLevel.INFO, message: 'Info Message' },
+]
+
+describe('DjangoMessagesService', () => {
+  let service: DjangoMessagesService
+
+  beforeEach(() => {
+    window['DJANGO_MESSAGES'] = messages
+    TestBed.configureTestingModule({
+      providers: [DjangoMessagesService],
+    })
+    service = TestBed.inject(DjangoMessagesService)
+  })
+
+  it('should retrieve global django messages if present', () => {
+    expect(service.get()).toEqual(messages)
+
+    window['DJANGO_MESSAGES'] = undefined
+    expect(service.get()).toEqual([])
+  })
+})
diff --git a/src-ui/src/app/services/django-messages.service.ts b/src-ui/src/app/services/django-messages.service.ts
new file mode 100644
index 00000000000..fddbe881a1f
--- /dev/null
+++ b/src-ui/src/app/services/django-messages.service.ts
@@ -0,0 +1,27 @@
+import { Injectable } from '@angular/core'
+
+// see https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/5.0/ref/contrib/messages/#message-tags
+export enum DjangoMessageLevel {
+  DEBUG = 'debug',
+  INFO = 'info',
+  SUCCESS = 'success',
+  WARNING = 'warning',
+  ERROR = 'error',
+}
+
+export interface DjangoMessage {
+  level: DjangoMessageLevel
+  message: string
+}
+
+@Injectable({
+  providedIn: 'root',
+})
+export class DjangoMessagesService {
+  constructor() {}
+
+  get(): DjangoMessage[] {
+    // These are embedded in the HTML as raw JS, the service is for convenience
+    return window['DJANGO_MESSAGES'] ?? []
+  }
+}

       </div>
       {% endif %}
 		</form>
+{% load allauth socialaccount %}
+{% get_providers as socialaccount_providers %}
+{% if socialaccount_providers %}
+    <p class="mt-3">{% translate "or sign in via" %}</p>
+    <ul class="m-0 p-0">
+        {% for provider in socialaccount_providers %}
+            {% if provider.id == "openid" %}
+                {% for brand in provider.get_brands %}
+                    {% provider_login_url provider openid=brand.openid_url process=process as href %}
+                <li class="d-grid mt-3"><a class="btn btn-secondary" href="{{ href }}">{{ brand.name }}</a></li>
+                {% endfor %}
+            {% else %}
+            {% provider_login_url provider process=process scope=scope auth_params=auth_params as href %}
+            <li class="d-grid mt-3">
+              <form class="d-grid" method="POST" action="{{ href }}">
+                {% csrf_token %}
+                <button type="submit" class="btn btn-secondary">{{ provider.name }}</button>
+              </form>
+            </li>
+            {% endif %}
+        {% endfor %}
+    </ul>
+{% endif %}
+    </div>
 	</body>
 </html>

+        <label for="inputEmail">{{ i18n_email }}</label>
+      </div>
+            {% if redirect_field_value %}

+                       name="{{ redirect_field_name }}"
+                       value="{{ redirect_field_value }}" />
+            {% endif %}
+      <div class="d-grid mt-3">
+        <button class="btn btn-lg btn-primary" type="submit">{% translate "Sign up" %}</button>
+      </div>
+		</form>
+    </div>
+	</body>
+</html>

+    def test_disconnect_social_account(self):

+        GIVEN:

+            - API call is made to disconnect a social account
+        THEN:

+        """
+        self.setupSocialAccount()
+
+        # Test with invalid id
+        response = self.client.post(

+            {"id": -1},
+        )
+
+        self.assertEqual(response.status_code, status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)
+
+        # Test with valid id

+
+        response = self.client.post(

+            {"id": social_account_id},
+        )
+

+        self.assertEqual(response.data, social_account_id)
+
+        self.assertEqual(
+            len(self.user.socialaccount_set.filter(pk=social_account_id)),
+            0,
+        )

diff --git a/src/paperless/adapter.py b/src/paperless/adapter.py
new file mode 100644
index 00000000000..98b0f11ba69
--- /dev/null
+++ b/src/paperless/adapter.py
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@
+from allauth.account.adapter import DefaultAccountAdapter
+from allauth.socialaccount.adapter import DefaultSocialAccountAdapter
+from django.conf import settings
+from django.urls import reverse
+
+
+class CustomAccountAdapter(DefaultAccountAdapter):
+    def is_open_for_signup(self, request):
+        allow_signups = super().is_open_for_signup(request)
+        # Override with setting, otherwise default to super.
+        return getattr(settings, "ACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS", allow_signups)
+
+
+class CustomSocialAccountAdapter(DefaultSocialAccountAdapter):
+    def is_open_for_signup(self, request, sociallogin):
+        allow_signups = super().is_open_for_signup(request, sociallogin)
+        # Override with setting, otherwise default to super.
+        return getattr(settings, "SOCIALACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS", allow_signups)
+
+    def get_connect_redirect_url(self, request, socialaccount):
+        """
+        Returns the default URL to redirect to after successfully
+        connecting a social account.
+        """
+        url = reverse("base")
+        return url
+
+    def populate_user(self, request, sociallogin, data):
+        # TODO: If default global permissions are implemented, should also be here
+        return super().populate_user(request, sociallogin, data)  # pragma: no cover

new file mode 100644
index 00000000000..ca79cbce027
--- /dev/null
+++ b/src/paperless/tests/test_adapter.py
@@ -0,0 +1,43 @@
+from allauth.account.adapter import get_adapter
+from allauth.socialaccount.adapter import get_adapter as get_social_adapter
+from django.conf import settings
+from django.test import TestCase
+from django.urls import reverse
+
+
+class TestCustomAccountAdapter(TestCase):
+    def test_is_open_for_signup(self):
+        adapter = get_adapter()
+
+        # Test when ACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS is True
+        settings.ACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS = True
+        self.assertTrue(adapter.is_open_for_signup(None))
+
+        # Test when ACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS is False
+        settings.ACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS = False
+        self.assertFalse(adapter.is_open_for_signup(None))
+
+
+class TestCustomSocialAccountAdapter(TestCase):
+    def test_is_open_for_signup(self):
+        adapter = get_social_adapter()
+
+        # Test when SOCIALACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS is True
+        settings.SOCIALACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS = True
+        self.assertTrue(adapter.is_open_for_signup(None, None))
+
+        # Test when SOCIALACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS is False
+        settings.SOCIALACCOUNT_ALLOW_SIGNUPS = False
+        self.assertFalse(adapter.is_open_for_signup(None, None))
+
+    def test_get_connect_redirect_url(self):
+        adapter = get_social_adapter()
+        request = None
+        socialaccount = None
+
+        # Test the default URL
+        expected_url = reverse("base")
+        self.assertEqual(
+            adapter.get_connect_redirect_url(request, socialaccount),
+            expected_url,
+        )

index 0f417b9abd1..1151ceed5e1 100644
--- a/src/paperless/views.py
+++ b/src/paperless/views.py
@@ -1,10 +1,13 @@
 import os
 from collections import OrderedDict
 
+from allauth.socialaccount.adapter import get_adapter
+from allauth.socialaccount.models import SocialAccount
 from django.contrib.auth.models import Group
 from django.contrib.auth.models import User
 from django.db.models.functions import Lower
 from django.http import HttpResponse
+from django.http import HttpResponseBadRequest
 from django.views.generic import View
 from django_filters.rest_framework import DjangoFilterBackend
 from rest_framework.authtoken.models import Token
@@ -14,6 +17,7 @@
 from rest_framework.permissions import DjangoObjectPermissions
 from rest_framework.permissions import IsAuthenticated
 from rest_framework.response import Response
+from rest_framework.views import APIView
 from rest_framework.viewsets import ModelViewSet
 
 from documents.permissions import PaperlessObjectPermissions
@@ -168,3 +172,54 @@ class ApplicationConfigurationViewSet(ModelViewSet):
 
     serializer_class = ApplicationConfigurationSerializer
     permission_classes = (IsAuthenticated, DjangoObjectPermissions)
+
+
+class DisconnectSocialAccountView(GenericAPIView):
+    """
+    Disconnects a social account provider from the user account
+    """
+
+    permission_classes = [IsAuthenticated]
+
+    def post(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
+        user = self.request.user
+
+        try:
+            account = user.socialaccount_set.get(pk=request.data["id"])
+            account_id = account.id
+            account.delete()
+            return Response(account_id)
+        except SocialAccount.DoesNotExist:
+            return HttpResponseBadRequest("Social account not found")
+
+
+class SocialAccountProvidersView(APIView):
+    """
+    List of social account providers
+    """
+
+    permission_classes = [IsAuthenticated]
+
+    def get(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
+        adapter = get_adapter()
+        providers = adapter.list_providers(request)
+        resp = [
+            {"name": p.name, "login_url": p.get_login_url(request, process="connect")}
+            for p in providers
+            if p.id != "openid"
+        ]
+
+        for openid_provider in filter(lambda p: p.id == "openid", providers):
+            resp += [
+                {
+                    "name": b["name"],
+                    "login_url": openid_provider.get_login_url(
+                        request,
+                        process="connect",
+                        openid=b["openid_url"],
+                    ),
+                }
+                for b in openid_provider.get_brands()
+            ]
+
+        return Response(sorted(resp, key=lambda p: p["name"]))

I'd greatly appreciate any feedback and code review.

I'll update the PR accordingly.

comments:
Thanks for the hard work. This does seem useful but I will note one thing which is that this adds two new system dependencies even for folks who will never use the feature. Obviously not inherently a 'bad' thing, but noting. Also its crazy to me that with all the packages we have already none of them can convert pdf to an image (I dont know the backend codebase enough to say, Im not questioning this, I just find that surprising!).

Anyway, will leave the review to the appropriate team. Thanks again for contributing

@shamoon 
thanks for having alook :+1: 
Actually, I first tried using the `parsers.py` `run_convert`:

https://github.com/paperless-ngx/paperless-ngx/blob/acab197a45d03c49fbac07ad756b02451f6b53ef/src/documents/parsers.py#L109-L122

The problem I encountered is that the `pyzbar` library (which decodes the barcode) requires either one of those:
` PIL / Pillow images, OpenCV / imageio / numpy ndarrays, and raw bytes` 

Imagemagick (which `run_convert` wraps), doesn't support those AFAIK. That is why I added `pdf2image`.

There is no size difference displayed by running `docker image ls`:
```
REPOSITORY              TAG                 IMAGE ID       CREATED          SIZE
paperless-ngx-dev       latest              6beab3d4b614   19 seconds ago   1.28GB
paperless_webserver     latest              d1e14147dccc   11 hours ago     1.28GB 
```

I'm personally fine with the trade off (new requirement vs. new feature), but maybe someone else has a different idea on the implementation?
Ok thanks for explaining that! Like I said, I leave the backend to you guys, just mentioning =)

Barcode processing is something requested in ocrmypdf/OCRmyPDF#747, where the developer offered a suggestion to use a plugin for  testing for barcodes.  Maybe that could replace the `pdf2image` in some way?

Interesting idea.
As far as I understand it, this just describes how to hook a script in ocrmypdf. 

The script itself uses ghostscript to convert the pdf to an image. The image gets the Barcode detected by zbar.

I personally would rather use pdf2image as a python library then use a hook to an external Programm (ghostscript) to convert a pdf to an image.

Hi @stumpylog 
thanks a lot for your code review! I incorporated your suggestions. Maybe you can have another look?
I still want to add a test for the `tasks.consume_file` routine. Also there is a race condition in the consumption process due to moving / renaming the file. It doesn't hinder anything, but produces a log entry. I'll have another look sometime later.

Looks like good fixes, thank you.

- if you rebase your branch from `dev`, that should fix the failing check
- the race condition sounds like what I'm trying to fix in #483, where a file isn't actually finished before consuming begins.  if that's the case, no need to look into it
- More tests are always good.  in fact, could you add a test or 2 of files which contain another type of barcode?  And/or QR code.  Something else that the library should be able to detect, but then should be ignored.

The build is trying to use pikepdf==5.0.1, built from source, which fails for a few reasons (no build tools + and upstream issue).  If you manually edit the version (change to pikepdf==5.1.0) in requirements.txt before trying to build, that will at least progress further.

Obviously stumpy is the person who will be most helpful here but a small thing is I don’t see why `--no-optional` should be removed, [the only optional npm dep at this time](https://github.com/paperless-ngx/paperless-ngx/blob/501d225f93a40472fd21455693975bd736b397e9/src-ui/package.json#L54) is a tool we use to run the e2e tests called cypress so for a docker build you shouldn’t need it. And it doesn’t install on (some) arm systems which is exactly why we made it optional. Again, just adding that small note.

+PAPERLESS_CONSUMER_ENABLE_BARCODES=<bool>
+    Enables the scanning and page separation based on detected barcodes.
+    This allows for scanning and adding multiple documents per uploaded
+    file, which are separated by one or multiple barcode pages.
+
+    For ease of use, it is suggested to use a standardized separation page,
+    e.g. `here <https://www.alliancegroup.co.uk/patch-codes.htm>`_.
+
+    If no barcodes are detected in the uploaded file, no page separation
+    will happen.
+
+    Defaults to false.
+
+
+PAPERLESS_CONSUMER_BARCODE_STRING=PATCHT
+  Defines the string to be detected as a separator barcode.
+  If paperless is used with the PATCH-T separator pages, users
+  shouldn't change this.
+
+  Defaults to "PATCHT"
+

+def barcode_reader(image) -> List[str]:
+    """
+    Read any barcodes contained in image
+    Returns a list containing all found barcodes
+    """
+    barcodes = []
+    # Decode the barcode image
+    detected_barcodes = pyzbar.decode(image)
+
+    if detected_barcodes:
+        # Traverse through all the detected barcodes in image
+        for barcode in detected_barcodes:
+            if barcode.data:
+                decoded_barcode = barcode.data.decode("utf-8")
+                barcodes.append(decoded_barcode)
+                logger.debug(
+                    f"Barcode of type {str(barcode.type)} found: {decoded_barcode}",
+                )
+    return barcodes
+
+
+def scan_file_for_separating_barcodes(filepath: str) -> List[int]:
+    """
+    Scan the provided file for page separating barcodes
+    Returns a list of pagenumbers, which separate the file
+    """
+    separator_page_numbers = []
+    separator_barcode = str(settings.CONSUMER_BARCODE_STRING)
+    # use a temporary directory in case the file os too big to handle in memory
+    with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as path:
+        pages_from_path = convert_from_path(filepath, output_folder=path)
+        for current_page_number, page in enumerate(pages_from_path):
+            current_barcodes = barcode_reader(page)
+            if separator_barcode in current_barcodes:
+                separator_page_numbers.append(current_page_number)
+    return separator_page_numbers
+
+
+def separate_pages(filepath: str, pages_to_split_on: List[int]) -> List[str]:
+    """
+    Separate the provided file on the pages_to_split_on.
+    The pages which are defined by page_numbers will be removed.
+    Returns a list of (temporary) filepaths to consume.
+    These will need to be deleted later.
+    """
+    os.makedirs(settings.SCRATCH_DIR, exist_ok=True)
+    tempdir = tempfile.mkdtemp(prefix="paperless-", dir=settings.SCRATCH_DIR)
+    fname = os.path.splitext(os.path.basename(filepath))[0]
+    pdf = Pdf.open(filepath)
+    document_paths = []
+    logger.debug(f"Temp dir is {str(tempdir)}")
+    if not pages_to_split_on:
+        logger.warning("No pages to split on!")
+    else:
+        # go from the first page to the first separator page
+        dst = Pdf.new()
+        for n, page in enumerate(pdf.pages):
+            if n < pages_to_split_on[0]:
+                dst.pages.append(page)
+        output_filename = "{}_document_0.pdf".format(fname)
+        savepath = os.path.join(tempdir, output_filename)
+        with open(savepath, "wb") as out:
+            dst.save(out)
+        document_paths = [savepath]
+
+        # iterate through the rest of the document
+        for count, page_number in enumerate(pages_to_split_on):
+            logger.debug(f"Count: {str(count)} page_number: {str(page_number)}")
+            dst = Pdf.new()
+            try:
+                next_page = pages_to_split_on[count + 1]
+            except IndexError:
+                next_page = len(pdf.pages)
+            # skip the first page_number. This contains the barcode page
+            for page in range(page_number + 1, next_page):
+                logger.debug(
+                    f"page_number: {str(page_number)} next_page: {str(next_page)}",
+                )
+                dst.pages.append(pdf.pages[page])
+            output_filename = "{}_document_{}.pdf".format(fname, str(count + 1))
+            logger.debug(f"pdf no:{str(count)} has {str(len(dst.pages))} pages")
+            savepath = os.path.join(tempdir, output_filename)
+            with open(savepath, "wb") as out:
+                dst.save(out)
+            document_paths.append(savepath)
+    logger.debug(f"Temp files are {str(document_paths)}")
+    return document_paths
+
+
+def save_to_dir(
+    filepath: str,
+    newname: str = None,
+    target_dir: str = settings.CONSUMPTION_DIR,
+):
+    """
+    Copies filepath to target_dir.
+    Optionally rename the file.
+    """
+    if os.path.isfile(filepath) and os.path.isdir(target_dir):
+        dst = shutil.copy(filepath, target_dir)
+        logging.debug(f"saved {str(filepath)} to {str(dst)}")
+        if newname:
+            dst_new = os.path.join(target_dir, newname)
+            logger.debug(f"moving {str(dst)} to {str(dst_new)}")
+            os.rename(dst, dst_new)
+    else:
+        logger.warning(f"{str(filepath)} or {str(target_dir)} don't exist.")
+
+
 def consume_file(

+        if separators:
+            logger.debug(f"Pages with separators found in: {str(path)}")
+            document_list = separate_pages(path, separators)
+        if document_list:
+            for n, document in enumerate(document_list):
+                # save to consumption dir
+                # rename it to the original filename  with number prefix
+                if override_filename:
+                    newname = f"{str(n)}_" + override_filename
+                else:

+                save_to_dir(document, newname=newname)
+            # if we got here, the document was successfully split
+            # and can safely be deleted
+            logger.debug("Deleting file {}".format(path))
+            os.unlink(path)
+            # notify the sender, otherwise the progress bar
+            # in the UI stays stuck
+            payload = {
+                "filename": override_filename,
+                "task_id": task_id,
+                "current_progress": 100,
+                "max_progress": 100,
+                "status": "SUCCESS",
+                "message": "finished",
+            }
+            try:
+                async_to_sync(get_channel_layer().group_send)(
+                    "status_updates",
+                    {"type": "status_update", "data": payload},
+                )
+            except OSError as e:
+                logger.warning("OSError. It could be, the broker cannot be reached.")
+                logger.warning(str(e))
+            return "File successfully split"
+

+        )
+        nonexistingdir = "/nowhere"
+        if os.path.isdir(nonexistingdir):
+            self.fail("non-existing dir exists")
+        else:
+            with self.assertLogs("paperless.tasks", level="WARNING") as cm:
+                tasks.save_to_dir(test_file, target_dir=nonexistingdir)
+            self.assertEqual(

+                ],
+            )

+    def test_save_to_dir3(self):
+        test_file = os.path.join(
+            os.path.dirname(__file__),
+            "samples",
+            "barcodes",
+            "patch-code-t.pdf",
+        )
+        tempdir = tempfile.mkdtemp(prefix="paperless-", dir=settings.SCRATCH_DIR)
+        tasks.save_to_dir(test_file, newname="newname.pdf", target_dir=tempdir)
+        target_file = os.path.join(tempdir, "newname.pdf")
+        self.assertTrue(os.path.isfile(target_file))
+
+    def test_barcode_splitter(self):
+        test_file = os.path.join(
+            os.path.dirname(__file__),
+            "samples",
+            "barcodes",
+            "patch-code-t-middle.pdf",
+        )

+        separators = tasks.scan_file_for_separating_barcodes(test_file)
+        self.assertTrue(separators)
+        document_list = tasks.separate_pages(test_file, separators)
+        self.assertTrue(document_list)
+        for document in document_list:
+            tasks.save_to_dir(document, target_dir=tempdir)
+        target_file1 = os.path.join(tempdir, "patch-code-t-middle_document_0.pdf")
+        target_file2 = os.path.join(tempdir, "patch-code-t-middle_document_1.pdf")
+        self.assertTrue(os.path.isfile(target_file1))
+        self.assertTrue(os.path.isfile(target_file2))
+
+    @override_settings(CONSUMER_ENABLE_BARCODES=True)
+    def test_consume_barcode_file(self):
+        test_file = os.path.join(
+            os.path.dirname(__file__),
+            "samples",
+            "barcodes",
+            "patch-code-t-middle.pdf",
+        )

+        shutil.copy(test_file, dst)
+
+        self.assertEqual(tasks.consume_file(dst), "File successfully split")

pr_title: Feature: Ability to consume mails and eml files
pr_body:
<!--
Note: All PRs with code changes should be targeted to the `dev` branch, pure documentation changes can target `main`
-->

## Proposed change

Add feature to consume emails (not only attachments) via paperless_mail or directly consume .eml files.
This feature should integrate into paperless_mail and be configured via mail rules.
A pdf is generated for previews, but the original mail is stored as .eml which can be opened by almost all mail programs.
The pdf is generated using Gotenbe

I find this very useful. Not an active dev, I just wonder if such a feature would be exactly why paperless needs over time a plugin architecture. Many people use paperless, as originally intended to deal with scanned documents. Email was added as a shortcut to add PDF attachments directly. A plugin-system would be really helpful here.

pr_body:
<!--
Note: All PRs with code changes should be targeted to the `dev` branch, pure documentation changes can target `main`
-->

## Proposed change

This mega-PR implements multi-user permission support, for reals 🎉. Obviously with this being humongous I'm sure there are problems and I would very much appreciate other peoples' thoughts / eyes / programming skills on this one, especially the backend stuff. Hopefully there aren't any fatal issues. There's 💯 no rush but I needed to kick it out
comments: Cool, so many thanks that you took that burden !!! 👍👍👍

WIth latest image provided, admin rights were granted to admin user. 👍 
The implementation does look really great and very promising.

A few things I recognized:
-  User cannot be created from the Settings menu. It does work for Groups but not for new users. These have to be created in Django Admin in advance before we can assign permissions or groups to them. Could it be that password field is missing?
- I wasn't able to create new Correspondents or Tags etc. with any account.
- I experienced the following behaviour: If no group is assigned to a document, all user can see it. That's fine. But if I assign a group to view permission, I would expect that only users who are member of that group can see the document. But it turns out that also other users are still able it. Is there a different intention on assigning and using groups?

Thanks for testing!
 
> A few things I recognized:
> 
> * User cannot be created from the Settings menu. It does work for Groups but not for new users. These have to be created in Django Admin in advance before we can assign permissions or groups to them. Could it be that password field is missing?

Fixed. The password issue is something I'd like some help with. Honestly, Im not sure the best way to approach passing passwords from the UI, especially since we cant guarantee users are using e.g. https (but maybe thats not 'our call'?)

> * I wasn't able to create new Correspondents or Tags etc. with any account.

Fixed.

> * I experienced the following behaviour: If no group is assigned to a document, all user can see it. That's fine. But if I assign a group to view permission, I would expect that only users who are member of that group can see the document. But it turns out that also other users are still able it. Is there a different intention on assigning and using groups?

Yes this is an issue and I agree its not obvious. At the moment all pre-existing objects have no 'owner' which means theyre visible to everyone, regardless of permissions (if you are the owner and give group permissions it would behave like you expected). I didnt add a way to set the owner via the UI because I thought it wouldn't be needed on an ongoing basis, since from now on all objects will have an owner. Thank you so much for this pull request / feature set! I think that Paperless will really profit from this.
So far, it is working really well for me.
 
 
### Issues
 
These are issues I encountered during testing:
 
 
**permission to view groups needed**
 
To give other users and groups permissions on elements, I as a user need the permission to see the groups and users.
Solution: 
Have a fixed setting, that allows that users can view groups and users.
It might be a good idea to also include the settings for groups in the UI, like the one for users. Currently, the permission to view groups has to be set through the Django Adminpanel.
 
 
**for me it was a braking change**
 
I guess it could be considered a breaking change: In my test-setup I was not able to use the regular docker-container again after using this one. Did anyone else have these issues?
Paperless itself started, but the Document views did not work anymore.
 
 
 
### Enhancements
 
Here are some ideas for enhancements:
 
**Transparency**
 
Show the owner of an element in the document tables, especially useful if you do not have the permission to edit and need to know who could make changes.
This concerns both the view in the frontend and the view in the Django admin panel.
 
 
**Permission inheritance**
 
If a group is granted edit permissions to an element, there are entries in edit and view for all persons of this group and the group itself. If I as a user would like to revoke this permission, I have a lot of work to remove each one individually.
 
There is a "clear all" option, but this only works if you had only one group. If I as a user granted access for two groups and would then like to revoke the permissions for one of them, I would have to clear all permissions and start all over again. Or I would have to know, who has which permissions in the group I would like to keep. 
 
Solution idea:
Permissions should be inherited from groups to users and from edit to view.
The result would be, that if you set edit permission for a group, the setting would be kept as a single enty, but "under the hood" every user of this group will be granted edit and viewing permissions.
 
 
**Possibility to set groups as file owner**
 
It could be a good idea, if it would be possible to set a group as owner of a document.
Permissions would then be applied, so that a user sees all of his files, all files of all groups he has access to, and all files that do not have an owner at all.
 
 
**Individual stats on dashboard**
 
As an owner, instead of the total file counts (total and inbox) I see my file counts as well as the ones of each group I am member of.
 
 
**Individual consume and data directory for each user / group**
 
The first part of the idea is, that each owner and each group has its own consumer directory. The respective owner could then be set automatically during import.
The second part: If there would be a base directory for each user and for each group for documents, this would allow to keep separate data structures outside of paperless.
 
I think this sounds easier as it is, maybe I could come up with a proposal for the implementation if it is interesting at all.
 
 
**File upload through UI**
 
Currently, the user that uploads a file through the UI is set as owner.
It would be great to have a dropdown in the UI (either directly underneath the upload box or within settings) to change that behaviour, so as a user I could decide to not set an owner during upload, set myself as owner or any group I am part of. 
Bonus: As an administrator I would be able to force an owner of a document through environment variables or even in the settings.
